ESPN, ABC, other Disney networks to go dark on YouTube TV after failed talks
data.description:
(Reuters) -Google's YouTube TV on Thursday said Disney's networks, including ESPN and ABC, will go dark on its platform after the two companies failed to reach a new licensing deal.

"Our contract with Disney has reached its renewal date, and we'll not agree to terms that disadvantage our members while benefiting Disney's TV products," YouTube TV said in a post on X.

Disney did not respond to a request for comment outside regular business hours.

(Reporting by Shubham Kalia and Chandni Shah in Bengaluru; Editing by Rashmi Aich)

BYD Shares Fall After Third-Quarter Profit Decline
data.description:
By Jiahui Huang


Chinese automaker BYD's shares fell sharply after the company posted declines in third-quarter profit and revenue.

BYD's Hong Kong-listed shares fell 3.3% to 100.80 Hong Kong dollars, equivalent to US$12.97, on Friday morning, compared with the 0.25% decline by the benchmark Hang Seng Index. Its Shenzhen-listed shares dropped 2.4%.

The carmaker late Thursday reported a 33% slide in third-quarter net profit and a 3.05% decline in revenue.

"Considering the unsuccessful smart driving strategy for 2025 and also the latest anti-involution trend in the China auto market, [BYD] is in a challenging phase with its losing market share," Nomura analysts said in a note.

That said, some analysts are more optimistic on the company's outlook due to its overseas expansion, and project improved operational metrics from the fourth quarter.

"We expect sequential improvement in volume, margin and earnings in the fourth quarter, driven by demand recovery in peak season, better product mix and operating leverage," HSBC Global Research analysts said in a note.

BYD, known for its wide range of low-cost electric vehicles, has faced pressure this year from Chinese authorities' push to halt a price war in the world's largest auto market.

The EV giant's expansion overseas should become another pillar of volume and earnings resilience, the HSBC analysts said. The international segment offers a robust counterbalance to headwinds in the domestic market, they added.

BYD's overseas sales are estimated to surpass 900,000 units this year, doubling from 2024, the HSBC analysts said.


Write to Jiahui Huang at jiahui.huang@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-30-25 2319ET

data.title: Japan Economic Data Show Signs of Strength -- Update
data.description:
By Megumi Fujikawa


TOKYO--The Japanese economy is showing some signs of improvement, a slew of data indicated Friday, amid heightened speculation over the timing of the Bank of Japan's next interest-rate hike.

Evidence of economic resilience could firm expectations that the central bank will resume monetary tightening soon, though it has only one more opportunity to do so this year.

The latest inflation print for the Tokyo metropolitan area--considered an early indicator of nationwide trends--showed that a key gauge of price growth remained above the BOJ's target.

Core consumer inflation, which excludes volatile fresh food prices, climbed 2.8% in October from a year earlier as the effects of water bill subsidies rolled out in the Tokyo area faded, government data showed.

That was faster than September's 2.5% rise and the 2.6% increase expected in a poll of economists by data provider Quick.

Seasonal factors may have influenced the print. October marks the start of the second half of the fiscal year, a period often conducive to price revisions, said Dai-Ichi Life Research Institute's Yoshiki Shinke.

Prices for many items went up during the month, showing that "firms' willingness to raise prices remains strong," the economist said. The Tokyo figures showed that food prices, excluding fresh items, rose 1.1% from the previous month.

The pickup in inflation is in line with the BOJ's forecasts as it continues to gauge when to resume monetary tightening.

The central bank on Thursday left its policy rate unchanged at 0.5% amid uncertainty about the impact of U.S. tariffs and domestic political shifts. It expects core consumer prices to rise 2.7% in the year ending March 2026.

Despite persistent inflation, consumer appetite recovered in September, according to separate government figures released Friday. Retail sales rose 0.5% from a year earlier, following a 0.9% fall in August.

Another set of figures signaled resilience in the industrial sector. Industrial production rose 2.2% in September from the previous month, compared with the 1.5% drop in August and economists' forecast for a 1.6% rise.

The activity prints suggest that third-quarter growth data, which is due Nov. 17, may show a milder-than-anticipated contraction, said Marcel Thieliant, head of Asia-Pacific at Capital Economics.

"The economy should return to growth this quarter," he said.

Though economists think the next BOJ rate hike is a matter of when, not if, some see it as difficult for the central bank to take action before next year, in part because new Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi prefers an accommodative monetary policy. Her cabinet is compiling an economic stimulus package that could have implications for monetary policymaking.

Given the current economic situation, the BOJ's decision to stand pat was "extremely reasonable," Japan's finance minister, Satsuki Katayama, said in a local media interview on Thursday. She added that it is much trickier in Japan to revive consumer sentiment than in the U.S., which has massive purchasing power.

The yen weakened to an eight-month low against the dollar this week, and remained soft as BOJ Gov. Kazuo Ueda reiterated his wait-and-see stance on Thursday.

The central bank governor wants to see more positive economic data, including on wage growth, before raising rates again.

The yen reached around 154.15 Friday morning in Tokyo.


Write to Megumi Fujikawa at megumi.fujikawa@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

10-30-25 2318ET

ANZ flags $721 million hit to second-half profit from restructuring, compliance costs
data.description:
(Reuters) -Australia's ANZ Group on Friday said it would take a A$1.11 billion ($721.28 million) after-tax profit hit in the second half due to charges related to restructuring, staff cuts and a major regulatory settlement.

The lender, Australia's fourth-largest by market capitalisation, said it is streamlining its core business units and bolstering risk management after a number of regulatory run-ins.

The bank said the charges will reduce its common equity tier 1 capital ratio by 19 basis points.

The company's shares were down 0.9% on Friday, while the S&P/ASX200 was up 0.4%.

ANZ said it would incur A$414 million in after-tax charges on redundancies and a A$264 million post-tax cost tied to settlements with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission to resolve several issues involving its markets and retail businesses.

The group will book a further A$78 million after-tax charge to wind down its Cashrewards business, which Chief Executive Nuno Matos has said was not a strategic priority.

Matos, the former HSBC personal banking and wealth chief, took ANZ's top job in May, replacing long-serving Chief Executive Shayne Elliott.

One of his first moves was to say that 3500 jobs and 1000 contractor positions would be removed from the bank in the next year to cut costs and trim its workforce.

The firm will also book a A$285 million post-tax charge on its stake in PT Bank Pan Indonesia after reviewing the value of the investment.

The bank has been paring back its Asian footprint in recent years, pivoting toward its core operations in Australia and New Zealand while retaining select partnerships in the region.

Separately, ANZ said it would incur A$68 million in after-tax costs linked to the accelerated integration of Suncorp Bank, after completion of the A$4.9 billion acquisition.

In early October, Matos said the bank would target a 12% return on tangible equity by 2028, up from 10.3% in the past financial year, while aiming to achieve a target of 13% by 2030.

The company will report its full-year results on November 10.

($1 = 1.5389 Australian dollars)

(Reporting by Scott Murdoch in Sydney and Rishav Chatterjee in Bengaluru; Editing by Anil D'Silva and Thomas Derpinghaus)

By Scott Murdoch and Rishav Chatterjee
